title: Kocher Criteria for Septic Arthritis in Children
description: Clinical prediction rule to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis in children presenting with hip pain, fever, and decreased range of motion

parameters.name: non_weight_bearing
parameters.description: Patient unable to bear weight on the affected limb

parameters.name: temperature_over_38_5
parameters.description: Temperature greater than 38.5°C (101.3°F) at presentation or in history

parameters.name: esr_over_40
parameters.description: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) greater than 40 mm/hr

parameters.name: wbc_over_12000
parameters.description: White blood cell count greater than 12,000 cells/mm³

result.name: septic_arthritis_probability
result.description: Risk assessment for septic arthritis based on number of predictors present

ranges.interpretation: Risk of septic arthritis <0.2-2%. Consider transient synovitis. May manage conservatively with close monitoring.
Risk of septic arthritis 3-9.5%. Consider laboratory studies and imaging. May observe with close follow-up.
Risk of septic arthritis 35-40%. Strong consideration for arthrocentesis or surgical drainage. Urgent orthopedic consultation recommended.
Risk of septic arthritis 72.8-93.1%. Arthrocentesis or urgent surgical drainage strongly indicated. Immediate orthopedic consultation and antibiotic therapy.
Risk of septic arthritis 93-99.6%. Urgent surgical drainage required. Immediate orthopedic consultation and empiric antibiotic therapy.

references: Kocher MS, Zurakowski D, Kasser JR. Differentiating between septic arthritis and transient synovitis of the hip in children: an evidence-based clinical prediction algorithm. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 1999 Dec;81(12):1662-70.

Caird MS, Flynn JM, Leung YL, Millman JE, D'Italia JG, Dormans JP. Factors distinguishing septic arthritis from transient synovitis of the hip in children. A prospective study. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 2006 Jun;88(6):1251-7.

Luhmann SJ, Jones A, Schootman M, Gordon JE, Schoenecker PL, Luhmann JD. Differentiation between septic arthritis and transient synovitis of the hip in children with clinical prediction algorithms. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 2004 May;86(5):956-62.
Del Beccaro MA, Champoux AN, Bockers T, Mendelman PM. Septic arthritis versus transient synovitis of the hip: the value of screening laboratory tests. Ann Emerg Med. 1992 Oct;21(10):1418-22.
formula: Count number of predictors present: (1) Non-weight bearing + (2) Temperature >38.5°C + (3) ESR >40 mm/hr + (4) WBC >12,000 cells/mm³
notes: Originally developed for pediatric patients with hip pain and suspected septic arthritis
Most validated in children aged 2-16 years presenting with hip symptoms
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other diagnostic modalities
C-reactive protein (CRP) >20 mg/L has been proposed as an additional predictor in some studies
Consider immediate arthrocentesis regardless of criteria if clinical suspicion is high
The algorithm assists in risk stratification but does not replace clinical assessment
Serial evaluation may be needed as clinical picture can evolve rapidly
Criteria may be less reliable in very young children (<2 years) or immunocompromised patients
